_comment: Gender Identity Counselor Competency Scale (GICCS), tested in a sample of US-American school counselors
datasetApaReference: Simons, Jack. Transgender and Intersex Advocacy: National Study of School Counselors: data file for sc adv for ti 092520.sav. Ann Arbor, MI: Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research [distributor], 2020-09-25. https://doi.org/10.3886/E122501V1-156444

instruments.instrumentApaReference: O’Hara, C., Dispenza, F., Brack, G., & Blood, R. A. C. (2013). The Preparedness of Counselors in Training to Work with Transgender Clients: A Mixed Methods Investigation. Journal of LGBT Issues in Counseling, 7(3), 236–256. https://doi.org/10.1080/15538605.2013.812929; Simons, J. D., Bahr, M. W., & Ramdas, S. M. (2022). Counselor competence gender identity scale: Measuring bias, knowledge, and skills among school counselors. Professional School Counseling, 26(1), Article 2156759X221110790. https://doi.org/10.1177/2156759X221110790

scales.scaleName: Gaining Knowledge/Skills to Counsel Gender Diverse Individuals
Awareness of Barriers to Gender Diverse Practice
Professional Exposure to Gender Diverse Individuals

items.itemStemText: Personally, I think being gender diverse is a mental disorder or a sin and can be treated through counseling or spiritual help.
I believe that gender diverse couples don’t need special rights (domestic partner benefits, or the right to marry) because that would undermine normal and traditional family values.
The lifestyle of a gender diverse counselee is unnatural or immoral.
When it comes to being gender diverse, I agree with the statement: “You should love the sinner but hate or condemn the sin.
I think that my counselees should accept some degree of conformity to traditional gender identities.
I believe that all gender diverse counselees must be discreet about their gender identity or expression around children.
It would be best if my clients viewed a non-gender diverse lifestyle as ideal.
I believe that gender diverse counselees will benefit most from counseling with a non-gender diverse counselor who endorses conventional values and norms.
It’s obvious that a relationship involving a gender diverse person is not as strong or as committed as one involving a non-gender diverse person.
I believe that being highly discreet about their gender identity is a trait that gender diverse counselees should work towards.
I have received adequate training and supervision to counsel gender diverse counselees.
At this point in my professional development, I feel competent, skilled, and qualified to counsel gender diverse counselees.
I feel competent to assess the mental health needs of a person who is gender diverse in a therapeutic setting.
I check up on my gender diverse counseling skills by monitoring my functioning/competency via consultation, supervision, and continuing education.
I have been to in-services, conference sessions, or workshops, which focused on gender diverse issues in counseling.
Currently, I do not have the skills or training to do a case presentation or consultation if my counselee were gender diverse.
I am aware that counselors frequently impose their values concerning gender identity or expression upon gender diverse clients.
Prejudicial concepts and fear of gender diverse people have permeated the counseling field.
I am aware of institutional barriers that may inhibit gender diverse people from using counseling services.
I am aware some research indicates that gender diverse counselees are more likely to be diagnosed with mental illnesses than are non-gender diverse counselees.
There are different psychological/social issues impacting gender diverse men versus gender diverse women.
Being born a non-gender diverse person in this society carries with it certain advantages.
Gender diverse counselees receive “less preferred” forms of counseling treatment than non-gender diverse counselees.
I feel that gender identity differences between counselor and client may serve as an initial barrier to effective counseling of gender diverse individuals.
I have experience counseling sexual minority gender diverse counselees.
I have experience counseling male-to-female gender diverse counselees.
I have experience counseling female-to-male gender diverse counselees.
I have experience counseling gender diverse couples.
I have done a counseling role-play as either the counselee or counselor involving a gender diverse issue.
